questions.title: Teens' Opinions About Online Privacy
questions.resources:
2018: Privacy Matters: Parents and Teens Share Attitudes and Opinions: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/research/quarterly-survey-series
2018: Social Media, Social Life: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/research/2018-social-media-social-life-executive-summary-web.pdf
questions.description: In 2018, researchers at Common Sense Media surveyed over 2,000 teens from around the United States. We asked them how they felt about technology, privacy, and life in the digital age. What did they have to say? See if you can guess!

imageMetadata.resources:
2018: Privacy Matters: Parents and Teens Share Attitudes and Opinions: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/research/quarterly-survey-series
2018: Social Media, Social Life: https://www.commonsensemedia.org/sites/default/files/uploads/research/2018-social-media-social-life-executive-summary-web.pdf

questions.question: What did teens report as their favorite ways of communicating with friends (in order of most to least favorite)?
What percentage of teens said they "never" or "almost never" read the terms of service when joining a social media app?
What percentage of teens said they've changed their social media privacy settings to limit what they share?
Changing your account to private means Instagram will stop collecting information from you.

questions.description: In the following polls, you can share your opinions on these issues. After responding, start a conversation with some classmates or friends. Did you agree or disagree with each statement? Why, or why not?
questions.title: Now it's your turn.

questions.question: It's OK for parents to share photos of their teens on social media without asking them first.
It's OK for younger kids to be on social media, even if the rules say you have to be at least 13 years old.
Social media sites should display everyone's real names to stop trolls.

questions.description: Many digital citizenship issues don't have clear, right-or-wrong answers. But you can learn more by starting conversations with your classmates and friends. And for more free resources, visit us at commonsense.org/digital-citizenship.
questions.title: Want to learn more?
